questions.question: A 38-year-old male, a known alcoholic, presents with intermittent epigastric pain for three months, described as a burning sensation occurring mainly after meals. He reports bloating, occasional nausea, and temporary relief with antacids. Upper GI endoscopy reveals peptic ulcers in the gastric antrum. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s gastritis?
questions.explanation: of peptic ulcers at the antrum on endoscopy, are most consistent with Type B gastritis . In this case, the underlying cause of the peptic ulcers is an infection with Helicobacter pylori. Type B Gastritis vs. Type A Gastritis: Feature Type B Gastritis Type A Gastritis Cause Primarily caused by H. pylori infection and long-term NSAID use Autoimmune condition, often associated with autoantibodies against parietal cells and intrinsic factor Location of Inflammation Antrum (lower part) of the stomach, near the pylorus Fundus (upper part) of the stomach, where parietal cells are found Symptoms Epigastric pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting, and ulceration in some cases. Often asymptomatic, but may cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort Associated Conditions Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), gastric cancer risk Pernicious anemia (due to vitamin B12 deficiency) Histological Findings Chronic inflammation, increased lymphocytes and neutrophils, often with atrophic changes Chronic inflammation, loss of parietal cells, and often atrophy of the gastric mucosa Risk Factors H. pylori infection, NSAIDs, alcohol, smoking Autoimmunity, genetic predisposition, vitamin B12 deficiency Treatment Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) Vitamin B12 supplementation and immune modulation; PPIs may also be used Prognosis If untreated, it can lead to peptic ulcers and an increased risk of gastric cancer. If untreated, it can result in pernicious anemia and an increased risk of gastric carcinoma. Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells (Option A): This usually causes Type A gastritis, which is caused by an autoimmune process affecting the stomach’s parietal cells, often resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency. Chronic alcohol consumption alone (Option C): While alcohol can irritate the stomach lining and contribute to gastritis, it is less likely to be the sole cause of peptic ulcers in this patient. Stress-related mucosal injury (Option D): This type of gastritis is typically associated with severe physical stress, such as trauma, surgery, or burns. It does not align with this patient's chronicity or risk factors.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of epigastric discomfort, bloating, and occasional nausea. An endoscopic gastric biopsy specimen reveals the following characteristic organism, as shown below. The patient is diagnosed with chronic gastritis. Which type of gastritis is least likely to be associated with this infection?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Granulomatous gastritis Explanation: Helicobacter pylori is a common cause of chronic gastritis and is typically associated with the following types: Antral predominant gastritis: Most common in early H. pylori infection, affecting the antrum of the stomach. Non-atrophic pangastritis: H. pylori can affect the entire stomach, but in the early stages, it usually does not cause atrophy. Corpus-predominant gastritis: It may develop as the infection progresses, often leading to atrophic changes in the stomach's corpus (body). However, granulomatous gastritis is not associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. It is more commonly seen in conditions like Crohn’s disease, sarcoidosis, or infections like tuberculosis. It is characterized by granuloma formation rather than the chronic inflammation typical of H. pylori-associated gastritis . Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2227, 2229, 2241, 2242. https://gut.bmj.com/content/66/1/6 https://journals.lww.com/jcge/Fulltext/2016/03000/Non_invasive_Tests_for_Helicobacter_pylori.2.aspx https://www.bmj.com/content/366/bmj.l4517

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with epigastric pain that worsens with meals and improves with antacids. Urea breath test is positive. Which of the following conditions is the patient least likely to be at increased risk for?
questions.explanation: adenocarcinoma, MALT lymphoma, and duodenal ulcers; while it plays a protective role in esophageal adenocarcinoma. Complications associated with Peptic Ulcer Disease: Bleeding Perforation Duodenal and gastric ulcers Malignancies: Gastric adenocarcinoma: Gastric ulcer >3 cm is a premalignant condition that can progress to adenocarcinoma. MALT lymphoma: 60-90% of patients - Complete remission on eradication of H. pylori infection. Conditions where H. pylori is protective: The mechanism underlying this protective effect is likely H. pylori–induced hypochlorhydria. GERD Barrett’s esophagus Esophageal adenocarcinoma (Option C) Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1280, 1281

questions.question: A 42-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of burning epigastric pain that occurs 1-2 hours after meals and is temporarily relieved by food. He also complains of vomiting. On examination, his heart rate is 115 beats per minute, and his temperature is 98.6°F. Mild epigastric tenderness is noted, and laboratory tests show mild anemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: suggests duodenal ulcer . Gastric Ulcer (GU) Duodenal Ulcer (DU) Common risk factors for both GU and DU: H. pylori, indiscriminate use of NSAIDS due to comorbidities in the patients like osteoarthritis or requiring total knee replacement, etc. > 6th-decade Premalignant condition. MC site: Lesser curvature of stomach. Basal/Nocturnal acid production: ↑ MC site: First part of duodenum or duodenal cap, usually within 3 cm of the pylorus. Size of Ulcer: <1 cm. Pain Pattern: Pain is precipitated by food. Pain Pattern: Pain occurs 90 min to 3 h after a meal and is relieved by food or antacids. Common Features: Epigastric pain (gnawing or burning sensation) Epigastric tenderness Tachycardia and Orthostasis caused by: Vomiting, may be due to pylorospasm or local edema GI bleeding Rigidity in the anterior abdominal wall is suggestive of perforation Succussion splash: Gastric outlet obstruction (due to pyloric stenosis, pylorospasm, or local edema due to ulcer in the peripyloric area or fibrosis extending to the duodenum). Acute pancreatitis (Option B): In pancreatitis, eating fatty food typically exacerbates the pain, causing a sudden onset of severe, sharp, and persistent epigastric discomfort that may radiate to the back. It is accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and elevated pancreatic enzymes. Gastric ulcer (Option C): Although gastric ulcers can cause epigastric pain, the patient's pain pattern ( occurring after meals and relieved by food ) is more characteristic of a duodenal ulcer. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (Option D): GERD primarily causes heartburn and regurgitation, with no significant vomiting or the pain relief pattern seen in this patient Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2441, 2442

questions.question: A patient is suspected to have peptic ulcer disease and endoscopy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following endoscopic findings is most consistent with peptic ulcer disease? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: recent hemorrhages. Workup for H.pylori: Noninvasive Test: For initial diagnosis and eradication Do a test after 4 weeks of stopping antibiotics. Before the test, stop antisecretory agents 7 days prior. UBT (urea breath test): The first test offered. Risk of false negatives in people using antibiotics in recent times. Stool antigen test: To minimise false negative reports Invasive Test: Upper GI Endoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy Endoscopy findings may reveal ulcers with a clean base with no recent hemorrhages. Rapid urease test (Also called as Clo-Test ): Stomach scraping is done and test results are analyzed. Biopsy: Can demonstrate the presence of extracellular bacteria with special stains. Note: If the patient is not willing for an endoscopy, the non-invasive approach is the best. Both UBT and UREASE can be false negatives due to recent use of: PPI Antibiotics Bismuth Surface protective agent Reduces the acid mucosa contact time Helps in the healing of ulcers. IOC to document PUD - UGIE >> Barium studies of proximal gut. Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) (Option A): Endoscopic findings of GAVE include characteristic longitudinal red streaks in the antrum resembling “watermelon stripes”. Dieulafoy's lesion (Option B): Endoscopic findings of Dieulafoy's lesion include a pinpoint, bleeding arterial vessel within normal-appearing mucosa. Gastric Polyps (Option D): Gastric polyps on endoscopy typically appear as raised, well-defined lesions, which can vary in size and shape, and may be sessile or pedunculated.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with hematemesis and melena for the past 2 days. He reports long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for chronic back pain. On examination, he is found to be pale and hypotensive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a bleeding duodenal ulcer, as shown below. Which artery is most likely involved in the bleeding?
questions.explanation: complicated by his long-term NSAID use. Gastroduodenal artery is the most common artery involved in bleeding from duodenal ulcers. Endoscopic image of a bleeding duodenal ulcer, indicated by the black arrow. Gastric Ulcer Duodenal Ulcer Common risk factors for both GU and DU: H.pylori and indiscriminate use of NSAIDs. Epigastric pain, described as a burning or gnawing discomfort, can be present in both DU and GU Epigastric tenderness Tachycardia or Orthostasis: Vomiting may be due to pylorospasm or local edema. The pain pattern in GU patients: Discomfort may be precipitated by food. The typical pain pattern in DU occurs 90 min to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. M/C site: Lesser curvature M/C site: The first part of the duodenum or duodenal cap is usually within 3 cm of the pylorus. questions.question: All of the following regimens can be used in managing H. pylori eradication except?

options.A: Triple therapy: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin
options.B: Quadruple therapy: PPI + Bismuth subsalicylate + Metronidazole + Tetracycline
options.C: Dual therapy: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) + Erythromycin
options.D: Hybrid therapy: PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin + Nitroimidazole

questions.explanation: common treatment regimens include combinations of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) with antibiotics. Dual therapy: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) + Erythromycin : Erythromycin is not effective against H.pylori. 1. Triple therapy: (Option A) PPI for 4-6 weeks, Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin for 2 weeks. 2. Quadruple therapy: (Option B) PPI Bismuth (Disadvantage: Blackish discoloration of the tongue) Tetracyclines Metronidazole 3. Hybrid therapy (Option D) For the patients who cannot tolerate two antibiotics at a time. PPI + Amoxicillin for 7 days o PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin + Nitroimidazole × 7 days. 4. LOAD In patients with macrolides-based resistance. L evofloxacin + O meprazole + A linia (Nitazoxanide) + D oxycycline. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2446-2447

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of intermittent epigastric pain, nausea, and bloating. He has a history of duodenal ulcers diagnosed 5 years ago, which were treated with antacids. He reports occasional indigestion. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a small duodenal ulcer. A biopsy confirms the presence of H. pylori infection. Which of the following conditions in this patient would warrant H. pylori eradication therapy? 1) Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) 2) Gastric lymphoma (MALT lymphoma) 3) Non-ulcer dyspepsia 4) Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
questions.explanation: cases . Indications of eradication of H.pylori: Most important indications: Peptic ulcer disease Gastric MALT lymphoma Other indications: patients with atrophic gastritis first degree relatives of patients with gastric cancer patients with unexplained iron deficiency anaemia patients with chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura H.pylori eradication is not indicated in IBS and Non-ulcer dyspepsia. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1954853/#:~:text=Eradication%20of%20H%20pylori%20infe ction,cancer%3B%20(d)%20patients%20with https://www.researchgate.net/publication/315371388_Helicobacter_ pylori_infection_A_recent_approach_to_diagnosis_and_management

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease was treated with triple therapy (omeprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin) for 14 days. Six weeks later, he presents with persistent epigastric discomfort. Which test is most appropriate to confirm the eradication of the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Urea breath test Explanation: The above-described case scenario is a condition caused by H. pylori, and the urea breath test (UBT) is the most appropriate non-invasive test to confirm the eradication of H. pylori after treatment. Tests used to evaluate H.Pylori eradication Urea breath test (Option A) It is a simple, non-invasive, highly sensitive and specific test. It is ideally performed at least 4 weeks after the completion of therapy to avoid any false negatives due to the residual effects of antibiotics or PPIs. Stool antigen test It is also a noninvasive test, and to avoid false negatives, it needs to be performed after 4 weeks of treatment . Biopsy-based histology tests It can be done to evaluate the success of the treatment. It can only be performed after 2 weeks of stopping PPIs and 6 weeks of stopping antibiotics. It is not commonly preferred. H. pylori serology (Option B) is not a preferred test because this test detects antibodies against H. pylori and after treatment, it may remain positive even if the infection has been eradicated, making it unsuitable for confirming eradication. Upper GI endoscopy (Option C) is not routinely required to confirm H. pylori eradication as this procedure is invasive and is not indicated in this case unless there are other red flags or complications. Rapid urease test (Option D), is an invasive test which is useful for diagnosing active infection during an endoscopy and generally not needed for routine post-treatment confirmation of eradication. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1323

questions.question: A 48-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been taking naproxen for the past 6 months. She presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and dark stools. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a gastric ulcer. What is the drug of choice for managing this condition?
questions.explanation: omeprazole or pantoprazole, as it helps to heal the ulcer, relieve pain, and promote faster mucosal recovery. They reduce gastric acid production by inhibiting the H+/K+ ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells. Management of NSAID induced gastric/ duodenal ulcer: Firstly, NSAID should be discontinued and they should be treated with PPIs or H2 receptor antagonists. In case of conditions where NSAID cannot be stopped, PPI is the drug of choice. For prophylactic management (in case of risk factors) Misoprostol Selective COX-2 inhibitor PPI is used Risk factors for NSAID-induced gastric/ duodenal ulcer: Advanced age History of PUD Concomitant use of Glucocorticoids High dose NSAIDs Multiple NSAIDs SSRIs Anticoagulants or Clopidogrel Concomitant Infection with H. pylori Cigarette Smoking Alcohol usage Misoprostol (Option A) is a prostaglandin analog that prevents NSAID-induced ulcers , hence used for prophylaxis. However, it is not the first-line treatment for active ulcers as it is less effective than PPIs in promoting ulcer healing. Sucralfate (Option B) is a cytoprotective agent that forms a protective barrier over the ulcer, but it is not as effective as PPIs in promoting ulcer healing. H2-receptor antagonists (Option D) reduce gastric acid secretion, and help in healing the gastric ulcer, however in the given condition as she is suffering from arthritis, she is likely to continue NSAIDs and H2-receptor antagonists is not preferred in this condition. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Page 2440, 2449

questions.question: A 52-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is prescribed omeprazole, for the management of his condition. Which of the following is not an anticipated adverse effect of long-term PPI use?
questions.explanation: associated with hypomagnesemia . Adverse effects of long-term usage of PPI Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) Fever, eosinophilia, and decreased urine output leading to Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) Bone pain (Option A ruled out) Long-term PPIs increase the risk of osteoporosis and stress fractures. Clostridium difficile infections Due to reduced gastric acidity , which normally acts as a barrier to bacterial growth, there is increased risk of C. difficile infections Community-Acquired Pneumonia (Option B ruled out) Increased incidence for CAP is seen due to impaired gastric defense , leading to increased bacterial colonization in the upper GI tract. Chronic kidney disease (Option C ruled out) Chronic or untreated AIN can progress to CKD over time. Hypomagnesemia (Option D) It can cause muscle cramps, tetany-like manifestations, and arrhythmias. Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s, The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 1075, 1076 pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6372031/.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with the finding shown in the image and has a family history of similar lesions. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following statements about the most probable condition is incorrect? a) Typically associated with a mutation in the STK11. b) Associated with bleeding and intussusception. c) Associated with alopecia, nail dystrophy, and malabsorption. d) Low or no risk of malignant transformation. e) Esophageal webs and glossitis are seen.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) c, d, e Explanation: The clinical features of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine, along with pigmentation around the mouth and a positive family history, point towards Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which is associated with mutations in STK11, bleeding, and intussusception. Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome: Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine and colon. Melanin pigmentation

questions.question: A patient presents with features suggestive of Boerhaave syndrome. What is the characteristic triad seen in this condition?

options.A: Multiple episodes of vomiting + chest pain + subcutaneous emphysema (Mackler’s triad)
options.B: Retching + Acute epigastric pain + Inability to pass NG tube (Borchardt’s triad)
options.C: Aortic stenosis + Deficiency of vWF + Lower GI bleed (Heyde syndrome)
options.D: Jaundice + Right upper quadrant pain + UGI bleed (Quincke triad)

questions.explanation: (Mackler’s triad) (Mackler’s triad) Explanation: Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema) is seen in Boerhaave syndrome. Boerhaave’s Syndrome: It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation , which allows gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema . Classic triad : Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. (Mackler’s triad) Symptoms : May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis. Physical exam : Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema). Complications : Pneumothorax, mediastinitis, and sepsis. Borchardt’s triad: Seen in Gastric volvulus (Option B) Retching + Acute epigastric pain + Inability to pass NG tube. Heyde syndrome (Option C) : Aortic stenosis + Deficiency of vWF + Lower GI bleed. Quincke triad: Seen in patients with hemobilia secondary to a hepatic artery aneurysm (Option D) Jaundice + Right upper quadrant pain + UGI bleed. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1127,1128

questions.question: All of the following classification systems can be used in GI bleeding except?
questions.explanation: pancreatitis, distinguishing between mild, moderate, and severe cases. Glasgow-Blatchford score (Option A) is used to assess the severity of upper GI bleeding and predict the need for intervention or hospitalisation. It includes parameters like hemoglobin level, blood pressure, heart rate, and the presence of melena or syncope. Forrest classification (Option B) is used to classify the appearance of ulcers during endoscopy and helps predict the risk of re-bleeding. Sarin classification (Option C) is used to assess the risk of bleeding from gastric varices , particularly in patients with portal hypertension . It helps in predicting the likelihood of variceal hemorrhage and the need for intervention. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 313, 1271 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4766829/
